analysis: Phenytoin is indeed a potent microsomal enzyme inducer (option a), which is well-established in pharmacology. It is also highly protein bound, primarily to albumin (option b), making this statement true as well. The statement regarding zero-order kinetics (option c) is misleading; phenytoin follows first-order kinetics at lower concentrations and only transitions to zero-order kinetics when the therapeutic range is exceeded, which is a critical point in understanding its pharmacokinetics. Lastly, the half-life of phenytoin does not increase with increasing doses; rather, it remains relatively constant due to the saturation of metabolic pathways, which is a hallmark of zero-order kinetics at higher concentrations (option d). Therefore, the only false statement among the options is option c, as it inaccurately describes the kinetics of phenytoin at lower concentrations. Thus, the correct answer is option c.
